dialogs.original: Hail, Dian! to perform thy just command,    I here confess myself the king of Tyre;    Who, frighted from my country, did wed    At Pentapolis the fair Thaisa.    At sea in childbed died she, but brought forth    A maid-child call'd Marina; who, O goddess,    Wears yet thy silver livery.   She at Tarsus    Was nursed with Cleon; who at fourteen years    He sought to murder:   but her better stars    Brought her to Mytilene; 'gainst whose shore    Riding, her fortunes brought the maid aboard us,    Where, by her own most clear remembrance, she    Made known herself my daughter.
dialogs.translated: Praise Diana! I'm doing what you asked: I'll tell the whole story here. I'm the king of Tyre. I left my country because I was afraid for my life, and married Thaisa in Pentapolis. She died giving birth to our daughter, Marina, at sea. Marina is still a virgin like you, Diana! Cleon took care of her in Tarsus, but when she was fourteen years old he tried to murder her. Luckily, she came to Mytilene, where, when I arrived, by good fortune she was brought aboard my ship and, by recounting her story, she made it clear she was my daughter.

dialogs.original: Voice and favour!You are, you areO royal Pericles!
dialogs.translated: I recognize that voice! You're, you'reoh, Pericles!

dialogs.original: What means the nun? she dies! help, gentlemen!
dialogs.translated: What did that nun say? Is she dead? Help her, gentlemen!

dialogs.original: Noble sir,If you have told Diana's altar true,This is your wife.
dialogs.translated: Sir, if you've told the truth just now at Diana's altar, this is your wife.

dialogs.original: Reverend appearer, no;I threw her overboard with these very arms.
dialogs.translated: Sir, it can't be. I threw her overboard with my own hands.

dialogs.original: Upon this coast, I warrant you.
dialogs.translated: Near this coast, I bet.

dialogs.original: 'Tis most certain.
dialogs.translated: Exactly.

dialogs.original: Look to the lady; O, she's but o'erjoy'd.    Early in blustering morn this lady was    Thrown upon this shore.   I oped the coffin,    Found there rich jewels; recover'd her, and placed her    Here in Diana's temple.
dialogs.translated: [To the nuns] Take care of the lady, she's just overexcited. [To PERICLES] Early one morning, this woman washed up on shore. I opened the coffin, found some expensive jewels inside, revived her, and made her a nun here in Diana's temple.

dialogs.original: May we see them?
dialogs.translated: Can we see the jewels?

dialogs.original: Great sir, they shall be brought you to my house,Whither I invite you. Look, Thaisa is recovered.
dialogs.translated: Of course, come to my house and I'll bring them to you. Look, Thaisa woke up.

dialogs.original: O, let me look!    If he be none of mine, my sanctity    Will to my sense bend no licentious ear,    But curb it, spite of seeing.   O, my lord,    Are you not Pericles? Like him you spake,    Like him you are: did you not name a tempest,    A birth, and death?
dialogs.translated: Let me look! If he's not my husband, my religious spirit won't let me get excited just by hearing; I'm inclined not to believe, having not seen. [She comes face to face with PERICLES] Oh, sir, are you Pericles? You spoke just like him, and you look just like him . . . did you mention a storm, a birth, and a death?

dialogs.original: The voice of dead Thaisa!
dialogs.translated: The voice of Thaisa, who's dead!

dialogs.original: That Thaisa am I, supposed deadAnd drown'd.
dialogs.translated: I am Thaisa, who you thought was dead and drowned.

dialogs.original: Immortal Dian!
dialogs.translated: Immortal Diana!

dialogs.original: Now I know you better.When we with tears parted Pentapolis,The king my father gave you such a ring.
dialogs.translated: Now I recognize you. When we left Pentapolis, my father, the king, gave you this ring.

dialogs.original: This, this: no more, you gods!   your present kindness    Makes my past miseries sports: you shall do well,    That on the touching of her lips I may    Melt and no more be seen.   O, come, be buried    A second time within these arms.
dialogs.translated: This, thisno more, gods! All this goodness makes the past pain seem like nothing. You'll do well if, when I kiss her, I melt and am never seen again! Oh, come and let me hold you. [PERICLES and THAISA embrace]

dialogs.original: My heartLeaps to be gone into my mother's bosom.
dialogs.translated: My heart jumps at the thought of being able to hug my own mother.

dialogs.original: Look, who kneels here! Flesh of thy flesh, Thaisa;Thy burden at the sea, and call'd MarinaFor she was yielded there.
dialogs.translated: Look who kneels here! This is your daughter, Thaisa, called "Marina" for the sea because that's where she was born.

dialogs.original: Blest, and mine own!
dialogs.translated: Bless you, daughter!

dialogs.original: Hail, madam, and my queen!
dialogs.translated: I salute you, my queen!

dialogs.original: I know you not.
dialogs.translated: I don't know you.

dialogs.original: You have heard me say, when I did fly from Tyre,    I left behind an ancient substitute:    Can you remember what I call'd the man?    I have named him oft.
dialogs.translated: Do you remember me saying that, when I left Tyre, I left an old friend behind? Do you remember his name? I've mentioned it many times.

dialogs.original: 'Twas Helicanus then.
dialogs.translated: It was Helicanus back then.

dialogs.original: Still confirmation:    Embrace him, dear Thaisa; this is he.    Now do I long to hear how you were found;    How possibly preserved; and who to thank,    Besides the gods, for this great miracle.
dialogs.translated: More confirmation! Give him a hug, Thaisa, this is Helicanus. Now I want to know how you were found, how you survived, and who I should thank (besides the gods) for this miracle.

dialogs.original: Lord Cerimon, my lord; this man,Through whom the gods have shown their power; that canFrom first to last resolve you.
dialogs.translated: Thank Lord Cerimon, dear, this man through whom the gods have shown their power. He can tell you everything from beginning to end.

dialogs.original: Reverend sir,    The gods can have no mortal officer    More like a god than you.   Will you deliver    How this dead queen re-lives?
dialogs.translated: Sir, you're the nearest thing to a god that a man can be. Can you explain how my queen came back to life?

dialogs.original: I will, my lord.    Beseech you, first go with me to my house,    Where shall be shown you all was found with her;    How she came placed here in the temple;    No needful thing omitted.
dialogs.translated: I can, sir. But first, let's go into my house, where I can show you everything we found with her. We'll explain how she came here to the temple, and we won't leave anything out.

dialogs.original: Pure Dian, bless thee for thy vision! I    Will offer night-oblations to thee.   Thaisa,    This prince, the fair-betrothed of your daughter,    Shall marry her at Pentapolis.   And now,    This ornament    Makes me look dismal will I clip to form;    And what this fourteen years no razor touch'd,    To grace thy marriage-day, I'll beautify.
dialogs.translated: Diana, bless your perfect plan! I will make a sacrifice to you tonight. Thaisa, this is Lysimachus, who's engaged to your daughter and is about to marry her in Pentapolis. And now, I'll shave off this long beard that I've grown for the last fourteen years. I'll look young again for your wedding day, Marina.

dialogs.original: Lord Cerimon hath letters of good credit, sir,My father's dead.
dialogs.translated: Lord Cerimon has received trustworthy letters saying my father's dead.

dialogs.original: Heavens make a star of him! Yet there, my queen,    We'll celebrate their nuptials, and ourselves    Will in that kingdom spend our following days:    Our son and daughter shall in Tyrus reign.    Lord Cerimon, we do our longing stay    To hear the rest untold: sir, lead's the way.
dialogs.translated: May the gods bless his soul. We'll go to Pentapolis to celebrate their wedding, and we'll stay there to rule that kingdom for the rest of our lives. Marina and Lysimachus will rule in Tyre. [To CERIMON] Lord Cerimon, we'll stay here until we hear the rest of the story! Sir, lead the way.
